WGhLfhcE7wBblpl6-fThlg.text: The decor is absolutely gorgeous - the space is huge and very well-decorated. It would be a great place to have an event or party....except for the food. MKC14yjhHfXksaM62FOuvA.text: Big surprise on a reawakening block of Fifth Avenue in downtown Pittsburgh.  Little would one expect that, coming in off the street for a Friday night dinner, one might find oneself in a modernized Tuscan villa, with stacked stone outer walls and exposed wooden beam ceilings.  The stagecraft is so lavishly conceived that my initial impression was one of concern - did they really want to use all this real estate, here in downtown Pittsburgh, to put on this great show?  But the set design was only the first big surprise.  We had been to Vallozzi's in Greensburg, and while it was an enjoyable experience, I hadn't remembered much about the menu.  Right off the bat, though, this menu started to speak to me.  After my recent experience with the burrata cheese-grenade at Portobello in Notting Hill, I was pleased to see a menu of cheese starters that included the burrata!  Since my dinner companions were all about moderation this evening, however, we instead went with a parmigiano reggiano appetizer, dressed with artichoke hearts and lemon chips.  The blend of these disparate tastes was astonshing, and a great overture to the blend of taste notes I was to experience during the rest of the evening.  I had the beet salad next, which was comprised of an eclectic blend of greens, beets, berries, citrus, olives, nuts - one of the best, most unique and unexpected pre-dinner salads I've had in some time.  My companions had the parma salad, and there were many appreciative oohs and ahhs all around.  Surprising to say, but my entree, after those two great courses, was the least astonishingly brilliant moment of the evening, but very enjoyable - a swordfish braciole, with a wild mushroom, pancetta, ricotta stuffing, in a tomato sauce with spinach, olives and leeks.  The sauce was heavier than advertised, and threatened to overpower the other tastes, but apart from that the entree was just as imaginative as what had come before.  My wife and her friend each had the fish of the day, the hogfish, baked whole, and her friend's boyfriend had the seafood risotto, none of which disappointed.  We topped off the evening with coffee and desserts - the boyfriend and I shared the "coffee and doughnuts," beignets with a chocolate-coffee-cream dipping sauce.  The wine list was impressive, and could also be seen as part of the Tuscan set design: I sat with my back to a bookcase of lovely Italian wines, and while we didn't order it, that Barolo behind me looked awfully tempting.  Instead we had a nice California Chardonnay with our fish.  The service was gracious and helpful, dealing with a number of substitutions and special instructions in exemplary fashion.  All in all, as great a dining experience as one could expect in downtown Pittsburgh.

0oLa4E_pG79MHV_8hnxBaA.text: Vallozzis is the underdog of the Pittsburgh bar scene. You rarely see it get mentioned in the 'best bars' lists, but it definitely earns its place among those other spots.  Wine list = excellent. Even better if you're going by the bottle, but the by-the-glass selections are terrific as well. (They get a great selection of Californian wines, including PEACHY CANYON!!! Paso Robles wine in PA!!) If wine's not your thing, they have an awesome cocktail menu with classics and originals, and specials on some of those as well.  Added bonus - the bartenders are just fabulous. Knowledgeable, quick, and friendly as can be.  As for the food: you really can't go wrong with a place that has a mozzarella bar. A mozzarella bar! Their entire charcuterie selection is delicious, and they serve their bread with a fluffy herb butter.  This is one of the restaurants in Pittsburgh that does octopus and does it well - perfectly grilled and tender.  But the star of the menu is the arancini. Whatever else you order, make room in you belly for that. TO DIE FOR. Crispy fried outside, creamy cheesy inside. I could eat three servings, and a single serving is a sizeable portion.  The bar area can certainly fill up, especially on a night when there's excitement downtown. So yes, sometimes you will walk past Vallozzis and be turned off by the sheer force of the crowd inside. But be strong and wait it out - you will not be disappointed with food, drink, or service. And that's why this underdog will always have a place in my bar-going heart.

BMOe2uwU3rKEj8rsUHL4Sw.text: I've been here for drinks a few times, so I was excited to find out my department was having our holiday office party here. This was a great venue for our group and I look forward to going back soon. Unfortunately there was no risotto as part of our menu but I've heard theirs is amazing. At least I have another reason to go back!

Was it the greatest gnocchi I have ever had? No. But it wasn't the worst and all pastas are made in house. The bread and ricotta/olive oil was a nice change up to the average olive oil. Keep in mind this restaurant is very pricey! Risotto is one of my favorite things, but I couldn't justify the price of $36. They had a Risotto on special with mushrooms and that was over $40. All in all, I feel it's a little over priced for just "ok" food.

YmJW8b6w35YbCaXv1LuzBA.text: This is my wife's favorite Italian restaurant in the Pittsburgh area. I'm a bit on the fence, but no matter which way you slice it, it's impressive. kW84nvH2SYclNrqEtO9O5w.text: I have dined at Vallozzis several times in the past few years as resident of Pittsburgh. I have enjoyed meals on the sidewalk with girlfriends, several group birthday dinners, intimate lunches and even solo drinks at the bar. I am so disappointed by my experience last night and encourage this restaurant to revisit their training protocols.   When I arrived at around 6:30pm, the restaurant was not busy at all. I walked towards the bar to wait for a friend and on my way, one member of a group of people in that area walked right into me, nearly knocking me off my feet and barely excusing herself. As I sat down at the bar, I watched her barrel towards a waitress to sort out the bill. When she returned, her party loudly debated the bill for several minutes. During all this time, neither of the two bartenders who were not busy as I was the only one seated at the time, greeted me or provided a menu. After at least 10 minutes, one bartender plopped down a menu without salutation. Moments later, 2 men who looked like they had just left a construction site sat one seat away from me. The bartender hurriedly greeted them with "good evening," exchanged pleasantries and took their drink orders. I still had not been served. Based on the service and the noise from the group, I decided to request a table in the restaurant from the host.  Upon my request, the host sat me at a booth near the back of the restaurant. I was awaiting one more guest and this was a good location. However, the waitress did not seem to be pleased or interested in serving me. She came to the table and stated, "Oh, you're waiting for one more." She filled my water glass but did not take my drink order. I asked for a glass of wine. Her disposition was unpleasant and she seemed annoyed. However, I watched as she pleasantly greeted and served patrons at two other tables that arrived after me. When my fiance arrived moments later, she filled his water glass but again failed to take a drink order, offer a greeting, discuss specials etc. Again, she moved to the other table across the aisle and engaged in these actions, as to be expected of a waitress in an upscale restaurant.   I went to the restroom and returned and still, no drink order had been taken for my fiance. Several minutes later, the waitress returned but again seemed distracted and nonplussed. She took the drink order and returned shortly with his beverage and bread. We had placed our menus on the table to signify that we were ready to order but we were not asked about our decision or informed about specials. And yet again, I watched this waitress walk across the room to another table and take out her notepad to document some part of their food orders.   At that point, I realized that we needed to make another decision about our dining experience. We paid for our beverages and then I briefly spoke with the manager. After describing what had taken place, I fully expected him to make an attempt to rectify this situation. Instead, he repeated several "I'm sorry's" but seemed most concerned with getting us to leave. Unbelievable!  I am not sure if Vallozi's is focusing on large group parties to generate the most revenue or if they no longer welcome African American patrons. Whatever the case, as a former customer and diner at many restaurants in the Downtown Pittsburgh area, I maintain that Vallozzi's offers the worst dining experience and is unapologetic about their failures in customer service. Never again and tell a friend!

yYLE24CiOobm39QLyTs-Ng.text: A strong choice for special-occasion dining downtown. xXFOHnn-EpqQ2U9pcC9Xlw.text: For Hurricane Irma refugees, Pittsburgh is an ideal refuge and Vallozzis is the place to eat. People turn up their noses and make a funny face when you say the word "Pittsburgh", and even our cab driver laughed out loud when we asked for a ride to the cultural district. But nestled in the heart of downtown is one the best Italian restaurants I have EVER been to... The place is absolutely gorgeous!!! It looks like Chef Ramsay put it together as it is both functional and aesthetically pleasing. One entire wall is an Italian countryside scene while another is adorned with massive clouds but its the wooden tables and bar that truly stand out... But, of course, it was the food that compelled me to make a next night reservation on the way out the door. The pizza carne appetizer (bathed in arugula) had the most unusual flavor I have ever tasted in an Italian restaurant! Its flavor profile was a garlic-ham hybrid that was a True culinary masterpiece... I was full when my gnocchi and sausage arrived but I surreptiously licked the bowl clean when nobody was looking! It tasted like a pizzaiola I ate canalside in Venice, a few years back; YES, it was THAT good!!! There must be a plethora of fine dining establishments in Pittsburgh if this place only gets three and a half yelp stars! We may be here awhile and Vallozzis will be my go to spot for the duration! Va bene!!!

gx0q-238dfVwVGvyf-d4WA.text: Stopped in at 11:30 for lunch with my coworkers. Our table reserved for 7 was set-up and we were sat immediately. We definitely beat the lunch rush, as it didn't start to fill until closer to 12:15. Simple breakdown...  Service: Excellent. The waitstaff is well-educated about the menu and as a former server, they hit all the marks for fine dining. The staff is friendly and make for a delightful experience. They offer complimentary coat check upon arrival.  Food: Our table ordered 3 chicken Parmesans, a spinach pizza, a chicken Waldorf salad, seared tuna salad and a grouping...the grouping meal is a neat concept. They have 4 groups to choose from and each group has 3 different types of food. You order one item from each group. For example, the dish at our table included beef tenderloin, shrimp with salsa, gnocchi and mozzarella basil salad. The portions are all tapas size but all together, it makes for a solid meal. Great way to sample different parts of the menu. No complaints about the food. I had the seared tuna salad and the taste was better than expected. I do not usually mix citrus with in my salads but the glaze on the grapefruit and oranges in this dish paired nicely with the bitter punch of the arugula.   The only reason I cannot issue 5 stars is that my meal was the priciest...and the smallest, with limited variety. The salad is served on a plate and not in a bowl. The only toppings are tuna, oranges and grapefruit. I would have felt that I got my moneys worth if the salad was arugula plus mixed greens with select vegetables mixed in.        Decor: classy and rustic. Exposed stone walls and dried flowers pressed into the doors. Beautiful!   The menu lists an option for GF pasta and for that reason, I will probably go back. Their pasta dishes sounded amazing and I love any chance to try a restaurant that caters to gluten intolerance!

aM05QkBG_Y-tCt2NceHexw.text: A nice, classy restaurant that sits in downtown Pittsburgh, Vallozzis is a great place to go for a date or special occasion.  The decor inside is very well-done; you can tell they really tried to put together an Italian feel. The lighting is also done well so that the ambiance is pretty dark, so that you have more privacy when you're eating. The tables are dimly lit by a single candle, which is nice except that they often burn out if a breeze passes by. Minor problem but it was annoying during my dinner. The service here is super professional, and you'll be impressed by how the waiters describe the dishes to you and how they move around the restaurant.  As for the food, my meat sauce pasta was excellent. There was the perfect blend of meat and sauce, and the al dente pasta really added that extra kick that just made the meal super satisfying. I also got to try a seafood alfredo pasta, which I wasn't as much impressed by. I thought the sauce was way too salty and seafood being naturally salty just made it worse. 3XsNs9fxmqZ8RSawCSBDiA.text: I was in Pittsburgh recently for a work event and it should tell you something that our group went here for dinner two nights in a row!   This restaurant is great to work with if you have a private group dinner that you want to arrange. They can help you set up a pre-selected menu and offer suggestions to guide your menu choices. Plus, they don't require an exorbitant food and drink minimum like some of the other nearby restaurants do.   Most importantly, the food is delicious here and the service was very good as well. The memorable choices that stand out to me were the arancini appetizer ($10 for this one) which is fried risotta balls served with buffalo mozzarella and marinara. Our table was fighting for every bite of this appetizer.   I ordered the caprese salad for myself ($14) and the presentation of fresh tomatoes, delicious mozzarella, and basil were just what I needed after a few days of conference food. For my main course, I ordered the ricotta ravioli at $18 and it was delicious and I even had enough for leftovers the next day.  All their pastas are made in-house and they also have select gluten free pastas which delighted one of my colleagues who eats a restricted gluten free diet. The pasta dishes range in price from $16-36 and they also have a section primarily for 'carne' (meat) dishes.   This place has a nice relaxed atmosphere and is willing to accommodate you and your group as best they can. I approve.

gZT61li7f-xw3tbOCCb_vg.text: My wife and I were celebrating our anniversary and we very looking forward to dining at Vallozzis. Reviews on TA and Yelp are very positive and we love Italian food.  First impressions - Very Good! when I made the reservation via Open Tabl, I note that we were celebrating our anniversary and requested a table that fit the occasion, if possible. We arrived 20 minutes early for our reservation and were greeted by the hostess who offed congratulations on the occasion. She asked us to take a seat in the bar until our table was ready. The bar area is large and open with some high top table. The atmosphere is nice and we looked forward to a great experience.  In using the Men's Room, I passed through the main dining area, which was very crowded and noisy. There were several two top tables open that were lined up on the far wall and sandwiched in between other tables. As I note this, I was happy that I had made the point of requesting a nice table. There were other smaller rooms and so I was sure we would be pleased with our table assignment.   Down Hill from there - much to my surprise and disappointment, when we were escorted to our table, we were seated at one of the tables in the main dining room that was open when AI had passed by 15 minutes earlier. My wife, who is petite, could barely squeeze by the table next to us to take her seat. UNBELIEVABLE! Because it was a special evening for us, I did not want want to make fuss as it might upset my wife.  Service - Well Below Average, at best. our server was nice but seemed clueless and she was hardly attentive. Despite the fact that the staff was aware that we were celebrating our anniversary, we were seated at one of the worst tables and not offered so much as a glass of wine, nor a basic dessert!   Food - average and over-priced. My wife ordered veal parm and I ordered  the braised beef ravioli. Both entrees were average. The veal was very thick and the red sauce bland. Atmosphere - beyond poor, unless you enjoy tables that are about 12" apart, located in a room with lousy acoustics. It was so loud, our ears were ringing when we left the restaurant.   FYI - I was concerned that I was being a little too critical and so I asked the couple seated next to us what they though of their meal and the dining experience. Conclusion - with so many new and highly rated restaurants downtown, I can not recommend Vallozzis.

urn4Ints-Cs6FJns4-KQlg.text: Came here 5pm on a Friday for dinner. Perfect timing, as the space was busy, but still had open seating. Around 7, the place packs up, so better make a reservation, especially if you have a big party.   The restaurant is divided into two spaces. One is casual, right upon entering the restaurant. A few heavy-set, wooden tables and benches for people to enjoy happy hour and casual bites. Then there's a separate, secluded section of the restaurant that is formal. White table linens, flower centerpieces, dim lighting. Perfect for formal/romantic/family/business gatherings.   Our waitress was warm and courteous. Quick, pleasant service.   The complementary bread was fresh. The olive oil and two spreads were amazing. Really enjoyed that fish spread! Wish there was more, as it's easy to eat a whole bucket full of that delicate goodness!  Got the burrata ($15) from the fresh cheese bar. Came with overly salty olives. The burrata itself was fresh and tender, so we enjoyed it.  Got $35 crabcake entrees. OH. MY. The BEST crabcakes I've ever had, and I've tried my fair share. No False modesty or exaggeration. Two enormous lump crab meat patties that had zero bread stuffing. Just chunks of crab meat. I couldn't believe how delicious they were! Very juicy and tender. Served with a side of grilled sweet corn and leeks. I'm not a fan of corn, but the flavors blew me away. A perfect combination of savory and delicate crabcake with sweet and crunchy corn and leeks. Everything was perfectly seasoned. Very fragrant spices. Savoring this dish was pure bliss. Couldn't finish one crabcake (the portion is huge!) so was very happy to bring such leftovers home. These crabcakes ruined crabcakes for me. After these, nothing else will ever compare. Needless to say, we were too stuffed for dessert.   Still dreaming of those crabcakes--will have to visit Pittsburgh just to taste them again! Definitely stop by to try them!

3vGjwmo_SE6gMxo0dDcaQw.text: I went here with 7 other colleagues on a Thursday night. QWlzm-bo85-rv5fz4DVOBg.text: My parents came into town the night before I was to move out of Pittsburgh. Since they were staying at the fairmont, we didn't want to stray too far from Downtown. We all agreed that italian food was what we were craving and after googling the menu, Vallozzi's seemed perfect.   First of all, make a reservation. Otherwise you will get the pretentious once-over and will be pointed, (yes, pointed) towards the "lounge" to...seat yourself. Call me crazy, but a place that offers the exact same menu (and pricing!) in two separate dining areas should never be 'seat yourself'. That threw me off. So, as we settled into our backless benches in the beautifully decorated self seating area, we took a look at the menu and waited for our waitress.  Strike two. The waitress came over, a dark haired girl who I regrettably did not get the name of, and it was all downhill from there. My dad asked what beers they might have on draft. This is a perfectly normal question, in my opinion. They had, what appeared to be, a full service bar. Not like we could see it entirely as they had higher seating filled between our bench seats and said bar. Anyway, she replied, "I don't have drafts." Okay...are we going to offer an alternative here? No? Alrighty then. So my dad names a random bottle and she says, as snooty as possible (yes, I used the word 'snooty'), "Sir, I don't *have* that on bottle." Oh! Okay! So.......oh, we're still playing the no alternatives game. My father, getting flustered with her lack of customer service skills, "Alright, well can you tell me what you might have since you don't have a beer list?" After listening to her blatantly rushed tone, he just picked the second thing she said. My mom orders. She comes to me and I say, "I'm going to look at the drink menu a bit more and order when you come back so water for now, please." Ladies and gents, I did not ever get that mixed drink. The two times she came back to bring my parent's drinks, I tried to speak and she walked away. Alright, I'll take this delicious water. Thanks!  And so we come to strike three. Because the menu is somewhat vast, (which is great! I loved that they gave us options!) my mother asked the waitress what is popular on the menu. The waitress replies, "We don't really have anything particularly popular. Everything is great." .....WHAT?! Now, while I've never personally served, I do have many friends in the industry. When someone asks you 'should I get this vs. this', you should probably have an answer. Or you maybe should know what a popular item is on your menu. Like I said, I have many friends in the service industry so I make sure to always be as courteous as possible and tip well. I couldn't hold my tongue anymore. As she was rambling off something unintelligible to my mom, I scoffed, shook my head, and looked at my father, "How can you be a waitress somewhere and not know what a popular seller is on your menu?"   Needless to say, the rest of our meal she was very fake nice, we probably had a hocker in our pasta, and I had to physically stop myself from being polite to her. Also, my parents always tip 25%+ and I can confirm that this lady got a tip that matched her sour attitude. Maybe she was having an off night, maybe she had too many tables and was overwhelmed. Not my problem and I'm bummed my parents and I had to experience it.  And after all this angry, waste of my time rambling, I do also have to confirm that portions were disappointing and the taste was just, 'so, what?'

4VvwC2Y6J7952ILbVZeOmA.text: I have never been to Vallozzi's and had my first experience on Saturday. Needless to say, I will not be back.   The atmosphere seemed promising: a warm, romantic feel with a lively crowd. Bar service was good with a decent selection to choose from. Dining area seems crammed. On multiple occasions we watched servers collide in the limited space.  Food was mediocre, at best, with the exception of dessert. Mozzarella bar appetizer was interesting and was a hit with our 6 person table, but I was extremely disappointed in my meal. I ordered the Buttermilk Fried Lobster Risotto (which sounded delicious). I was looking forward to a rich, creamy dish on a cold night! When I received my meal, I was disappointed to see that my "risotto" was more "rice pilaf," with almost non-existent moisture. There were also diced red peppers mixed in which, due to possibly misreading the menu, I was unaware came with the dish and which I can not eat. So I spent half my meal picking around them.  Fried lobster was tasty, but the lobster that was mixed into the "risotto" was rubbery and overcooked. All in all, so not worth the $32! Dessert was FANTASTIC. The table shared a seasonal cannolli (pistachio) and an order of the bread pudding. Both were delicious.  Our server, however, was HORRENDOUS!!! He was inattentive, borderline rude at times and we seemed like an inconvenience to him. He would disappear for 15-30 minutes at a time and would look in a different direction if anyone from our table flagged him down. We ordered a bottle of wine for the table which he them plopped on the table (No drink that he served us was set nicely down. All were dropped from at least a 2 inch height!) and was left unopened until we flagged him down 20 minutes later, to which his comment was "Oh, I thought you had a cork screw." When we placed our meal orders, I asked for a 2nd drink from the bar and did not receive said drink until our dessert was served. Another guest at my table was not served her dessert beverage until the check came. And then there was the check. When the check came, it was one single check for 6 people, even after we asked at the beginning of the meal to have the check split into two separate ones. So he was asked to put 2/3s of the bill on one card and the remainder on another card. He screwed this up too! Charging both cards the incorrect amount then disappearing before we could complain.  All in all it was one of the WORST dining experiences I have ever had. Not worth the price of the food to dine there and be treated that way. Serving staff need to be retrained on customer service, especially on busy weekend evenings. I will not be returning to Vallozzi's.

7JWpmwiyDac5FasCHaDPxQ.text: Let's just say if you have tickets to a show you better allow yourself a good 2.5 hours to eat and enjoy your meal because reservations at 6:15pm to be sure we made an 8 pm show was not enough time.  The night started out great.  We arrive ( 4 in our party) at 6:15pm and were immediately seated at a nice table in the back.  (Bonus) The atmosphere was very nice.  (Bonus) Our waiter Chris was nice enough (and I do not blame him for what happened).  He took our order after a respectable 5 or 10 minutes.  We informed him of our 8pm show time and he assured us that we will have plenty of time.  We ordered the turtle soup, some kind of risotto balls, salads, and our main dishes.  Around 7:15pm we asked what the status was on our appetizers as we had not yet received any.  Shortly after, our soups, salads, risotto balls all came out at the same time.  The turtle bisque was pretty good as was the caesar salad.  I thought it unusual that everything would come out together but whatever.  7:35pm we were waiting for our entrees and reminded Chris about our 8pm show.  7:40pm our entrees arrived.  We asked for the check immediately and scarfed down our entrees.  Which were just ok.  The Bird asked to see the Manager about the delay and stated that if 6:15pm was not enough time for us to have dinner there and catch an 8pm show they should have just told us when we made the reservations.  He only said that they do not make excuses and that the bottle of wine was on the house. (A nice gesture I give them that).  No one in our party had time to finish their entrees and were all "bloated" from wolfing it down.  Plus we never did receive our check.  The manager eventually brought it over and of course it was not divided as we requested when our orders were taken so hence more delay.    Funny thing is, I did read theses reviews (the majority being negative ) and my buddy was even advised not to try Vallozzi's by a friend who happens to own a restaurant in the south hills but I had to try it myself.  I think we all learned the hard way tonight.  As far as the food goes, like I said nothing special and in fact I am still feeling a little ill some 4 hours later.  Vallozzi's, please if you need over 2 hours to prepare a meal that is quite alright, but don't tell your customers differently.  (We ran into another couple at the show who were also late due to their dining at Vallozzi's ).  Such a nice place but we will never go there again.  Sorry.

tnUTpfUSh5LCy7wNNXVZug.text: I have been here before and enjoyed it, but today's unexpected lunch option blew me away.    The decor is lovely and the ambiance very nice for a downtown swanky restaurant.  What's weird - in a very good way - is the music.  You would expect this place to have pretentious classic or jazz playing, but instead you are treated to some fantastic mix that sounds like something from WYEP.  Lovely surprise.   When I walked in, I was given the drink menu which struck me as a bit odd for lunch.  While I am all for drunken afternoons, I feel that my company would have a bit of a problem with it - as would most companies within walking distance.  But I was also handed a strange 4 course menu.  This was awesome.  It was broken into 4 courses which are served on the same plate as a healthy and nutritious 4 course meal.  Tons of choices, but for today, I picked: 1. Arugula with goat cheese and brambleberries (read blackberries, raspberries and blueberries) - There was no dressing which at first struck me as odd, but as I stabbed through some arugula, berries and goat cheese all in one bite, I realized that it didn't need any.  Perfect combination.  2. Braised escarole with beans and pancetta - A bit salty for the pancetta, but you expect that with this combination.  It was a bit mushier than I have had other places (which might be their "thing"... see below), but the flavor was pretty out of this world. 3. Scallops with peach salsa - Just awesome.  The salsa was both sweet and spicy and the scallops were seared perfectly.  4. Polenta with fennel sausage and peppers - By far the most disappointing of the quadrants.  The polenta was too mushy for my tastes and there was not nearly enough sausage.  I will definitely be back to pick 4 more choices.  Oh and this was all for $14.  Maybe more than a regular lunch, but with these high end choices, well worth the money.
